description: If n = Product (p_j^k_j) then a(n) = Product (k_j^p_j).
comments: For any n, the sequence n, a(n), a(a(n)), a(a(a(n))), ... is eventually periodic with period <= 2 [Farrokhi]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 25 2009a(A005117(n)) = 1; a(A013929(n)) > 1; A010052(a(A122132(n))) = 1. [_Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 17 2012]
references: M. Farrokhi, Problem 11315, Amer. Math. Monthly, 116 (2009), 470. - from _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 25 2009
links: M. F. Hasler, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e) = e^p. - _David W. Wilson_, Aug 01, 2001.
maple: A008477 := proc(n) local e,j; e := ifactors(n)[2]:mul (e[j][2]^e[j][1], j=1..nops(e)) end:seq (A008477(n), n=1..60);# - Peter Luschny, Jan 17 2010
mathematica: Prepend[ Array[ Times @@ Map[ Power @@ RotateLeft[ #1, 1 ]&, FactorInteger[ # ] ]&, 100, 2 ], 1 ]Table[Times@@(First[#]^Last[#]&/@Transpose[Reverse[ Transpose[ FactorInteger[ n]]]]),{n,80}] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jul 22 2014 *)
prog: (Haskell)a008477 n = product $ zipWith (^) (a124010_row n) (a027748_row n)-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 17 2012(PARI) A008477(n)=factorback(factor(n)*[0,1;1,0])  \\ _M. F. Hasler_, May 20 2012
